description: This course is an introductory graduate course on computer architecture with an emphasis on a quantitative approach to cost/performance design tradeoffs. The course covers the fundamentals of classical and modern uniprocessor design: performance and cost issues, instruction sets, pipelining, superscalar, out-of-order, and speculative execution mechanisms, caches, physical memory, virtual memory, and I/O. Other topics include: static scheduling, VLIW and EPIC, software speculation, long (SIMD) and short (multimedia) vector execution, multithreading, and an introduction to shared memory multiprocessors.
name: COMPUTER ARCHITECTURE

values.comments: Students found the general content of the course to be interesting. However, students felt that the professor was extremely unapproachable during office hours and was reluctant to answer questions. Additionally, students thought that the exams were too long and covered too much material.
